identified-content.object.title: 101 Dalmatians (Movie)
identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Media, Entertainment and Publishing
Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Fashion, Beauty and Fitness

abstract.p: Practice in Ulaan Baatar, Mongolia, of killing stray dogs and using their hides in coats noted in light of film 101 Dalmatians (S)

block.p: After viewing Disney's live-action version of ''101 Dalmatians,'' opening next week, your kids may look to you and ask: ''Do people really skin dogs to make coats?'' You can truthfully say: Um, Disney doesn't. (''Our animals were treated better than most humans,'' boasts the movie's zoologically correct press kit; ''cast and crew were made to walk through foot baths of disinfectant before entering a 'puppy area.' '') But don't mention Ulaan Baatar, Mongolia, where overabundant stray dogs are gunned down, skinned and made into parkas that are popular with Russians. But surely pup couture can't happen here? Don't be so sure. Moenkhtsetseg, the owner of a Mongolian dog-pelt company, has suggested, Cruella-like, using dog farms to usher in the age of mass producton and foreign exports.
